column4: Is there any command-line tool I can run that gives a report such as "looking up domain foo.bar on nameserver aaa.bbb.ccc.ddd takes Z (milli)seconds?" nslookup seems to be giving results that disagree with how ping is behaving when pinging a domain versus an IP address
use dig?
/ danbhfive: all right, I'll try those. Thanks :)
sure
would you try visiting www.tpl.toronto.on.ca? it's the toronto public library.. I'm curious to see if it loads up super fast for you in windows (1-3 seconds) while slow in linux (20+ seconds)
both about equal speed, 1.13 on win, .95 on firefox/lin.
interesting.. i'm getting a few people on ##linux with slower results.. those were times in "seconds" right?
yes, from a 1gbit fiber line.
heh well with 1gbit its pretty hard to load anything slow unless the server itself is slow.
if it matters, chrome took about 17 seconds to load it...weird.
just out of curiosity, have you done anything with your linux install that's changed how the ethernet card behaves? MTU sizes, etc?
tried it from a Ubuntu machine and a CentOS machine, both loaded <1s in Firefox and 10-20 seconds in Chrome. Both are clean install systems with the exception of a custom mplayer.
hmm.. it may be a driver problem with my specific network card or linux doesn't like my router then, as even doing an attempt to load the site from ubuntu's boot CD is slow... bizarre

I'd say it was something on the sonicwall nat/dmz switch but if chrome loads it slow then I'd have to go with something in linux itself. Does the server do load balancing/web server do any kind of scripts/etc based on OS type?
i'm not too sure to be honest... I just always thought the site was slow by default until I tried loading it up one of the few times I was in windows and was disturbed by the difference in speed

dont have time to look through the scripting but I'm guessing it loads an alternate site based on which OS it detects, only thing I can think of. Or a load balancing system that does the same based on OS type.
maybe i'll try installing firefox's user agent plugin :)
give it a shot, can't hurt =)
run the app as chroot/different user with restricted permissions?
/ usser hmm.. ok, thank you :)

/ usser that user would still be able to access the internet though, no? ie: the software could open up a new socket and connect elsewhere .. is there any way of having that program run without manually removing eth0 from ifconfig?
what usser said =)
chroot is powerful, really powerful. Look up guides on howtoforge and it should explain how you need to set it up to block networking.
